nodes.label: Bedrock
nodes.description: The lithospheric substrate upon which all urban form rests. Bedrock determines foundational bearing capacity, excavation feasibility, and seismic transmission characteristics. It is the immutable constraint that precedes all human intention.

nodes.label: Water Tables
nodes.description: Subsurface aquifer levels that govern foundation design, basement feasibility, and long-term settlement risk. Rising water tables under climate change threaten existing infrastructure assumptions.

nodes.label: Solar Potential
nodes.description: The incident solar radiation available at a given latitude and microclimate. Determines photovoltaic viability, passive heating loads, and daylight autonomy calculations for building performance.

nodes.label: Material Reservoirs
nodes.description: Finite stocks of sand, aggregate, timber, and steel feedstocks. Urban growth depletes planetary material budgets; this node tracks the metabolic throughput required to build and maintain cities.

nodes.label: Hydrography
nodes.description: Surface water systems including rivers, watersheds, and flood zones. Historical flood depths establish the 'Baseline City' constraints that precede any development proposal.

nodes.label: Energy Grid
nodes.description: The electrical distribution network that powers all urban computation and actuation. Grid capacity limits determine how many robots, sensors, and data centers a district can metabolically support.

nodes.label: Climate Cycles
nodes.description: Long-term atmospheric patterns including temperature trends, precipitation regimes, and extreme weather frequency. These cycles establish the evolutionary logic that shapes urban adaptation.

nodes.label: Soil Chemistry
nodes.description: The geochemical composition of urban soils, including contamination legacies from industrial land use. Brownfield remediation costs and ecological restoration potential derive from this substrate.

nodes.label: Parcels
nodes.description: The fundamental unit of land ownership and regulatory control. Every parcel carries a unique identifier that anchors all other data layers to a specific location in physical and legal space.

nodes.label: Building Footprints
nodes.description: The ground-plane projection of built structures. Footprints define lot coverage, establish setback compliance, and serve as the geometric anchor for 3D massing extrapolation.

nodes.label: Stable IDs
nodes.description: Persistent identifiers that survive administrative boundary changes, ownership transfers, and physical modifications. The 'Identity Spine' ensures all data layers snap to consistent spatial truth.

nodes.label: Rights-of-Way
nodes.description: Legal corridors for movement: streets, sidewalks, easements, and utility paths. Rights-of-way define the connective tissue between parcels and determine accessibility for humans and machines alike.

nodes.label: Infrastructure Networks
nodes.description: Water mains, sewer lines, telecommunications conduits, and district energy systems. These buried networks represent massive sunk capital and constrain future development patterns.

nodes.label: Transit Networks
nodes.description: Fixed-route public transportation systems: rail, bus rapid transit, and ferry lines. Transit access fundamentally reshapes land value gradients and density feasibility.

nodes.label: Spatial Mode: Contest
nodes.description: Zones where human and synthetic actors compete for the same space-time slots. Delivery robots blocking sidewalks, autonomous vehicles in mixed trafficâ€”friction is the dominant interaction pattern.

nodes.label: Spatial Mode: Coexist
nodes.description: Zones where humans and machines share space through negotiated protocols. Time-sharing, designated lanes, and behavioral norms enable parallel operation without constant conflict.

nodes.label: Spatial Mode: Converge
nodes.description: Zones where human-machine integration becomes seamless. Exoskeletons, neural interfaces, and collaborative robotics blur the boundary between biological and synthetic actors.

nodes.label: IoT Sensors
nodes.description: Distributed environmental sensors measuring air quality, noise levels, pedestrian counts, and infrastructure stress. These nodes transform physical phenomena into data streams for urban intelligence.

nodes.label: Actuators
nodes.description: Mechanical systems that translate digital commands into physical action: traffic signals, smart locks, HVAC controls, and dynamic facades. The motor neurons of the urban nervous system.

nodes.label: Embodied AI: Robots
nodes.description: Autonomous mobile robots performing delivery, security, cleaning, and maintenance tasks. These synthetic workers navigate physical space while subscribing to the Agentic Council for ethical reasoning.

nodes.label: Embodied AI: Drones
nodes.description: Aerial autonomous vehicles for inspection, delivery, and surveillance. Drones operate in the vertical dimension, requiring new volumetric rights-of-way and acoustic impact considerations.

nodes.label: Edge Compute Nodes
nodes.description: Distributed processing units that perform low-latency inference at the network edge. Edge nodes reduce cloud dependency and enable real-time response for safety-critical applications.

nodes.label: Telecommunications
nodes.description: 5G towers, fiber optic backbones, and mesh networks that carry urban data. Bandwidth and latency characteristics determine which synthetic actors can operate in which locations.

nodes.label: Autonomous Vehicles
nodes.description: Self-driving cars, trucks, and shuttles that reshape urban mobility patterns. AVs require new curb management protocols and threaten to induce sprawl if not carefully governed.

nodes.label: Zoning Codes
nodes.description: The legal text that defines permitted uses, densities, and building forms for each parcel. Zoning translates political intent into geometric constraint, shaping the physical city.

nodes.label: Constraint Objects
nodes.description: Computable representations of regulatory limits: FAR calculations, setback distances, height planes, and parking ratios. These objects make law machine-readable and auditable.

nodes.label: FAR Limits
nodes.description: Floor Area Ratio: the maximum buildable square footage relative to lot size. FAR is the primary lever controlling density and directly determines development economics.

nodes.label: Setbacks
nodes.description: Required distances between buildings and property lines. Setbacks shape street character, ensure light access, and create the negative space that defines urban form.

nodes.label: Height Limits
nodes.description: Maximum building heights established by zoning, aviation safety, or view protection. Height limits shape the skyline and distribute vertical development potential across the city.

nodes.label: Void Markers
nodes.description: Identified gaps where existing regulatory frameworks fail to address emerging conditions: robot occupancy standards, drone corridors, autonomous vehicle liability. Voids signal where law must evolve.

nodes.label: Knowledge Graphs
nodes.description: Semantic networks that encode relationships between urban entities: which parcel is governed by which zone, which zone permits which uses, which uses generate which impacts.

nodes.label: Entitlements
nodes.description: Approved development rights beyond base zoning: variances, conditional use permits, and negotiated bonuses. Entitlements represent stored political capital converted into buildable square footage.

nodes.label: Environmental Review
nodes.description: CEQA, NEPA, and equivalent impact assessment requirements. Environmental review translates ecological and social externalities into procedural constraints on development approval.

nodes.label: Market Agent
nodes.description: A synthetic reasoner optimizing for financial return: IRR, cap rates, and exit valuations. The Market Agent stress-tests development feasibility against capital market conditions and risk-adjusted returns.

nodes.label: Policy Agent
nodes.description: A synthetic reasoner interpreting regulatory intent and procedural constraints. The Policy Agent translates zoning text into actionable guidance and flags compliance risks.

nodes.label: Climate Agent
nodes.description: A synthetic reasoner modeling physical climate risk: sea level rise, heat island effects, wildfire exposure, and flood probability. The Climate Agent injects planetary boundaries into feasibility analysis.

nodes.label: Infrastructure Agent
nodes.description: A synthetic reasoner evaluating capacity constraints: utility loads, traffic generation, and service availability. The Infrastructure Agent determines whether the city can metabolically support proposed development.

nodes.label: Community Agent
nodes.description: A synthetic reasoner representing stakeholder interests: displacement risk, affordability impacts, and neighborhood character. The Community Agent ensures social friction enters the feasibility calculation.

nodes.label: Consensus Artifacts
nodes.description: The documented agreements and disagreements produced by agent deliberation. Consensus artifacts make the reasoning process transparent and auditable, exposing which trade-offs were accepted.

nodes.label: Probability Cones
nodes.description: Spatial visualizations of scenario uncertainty. Where agents disagree, probability cones show the range of possible futures, making plural outcomes legible rather than collapsing to false precision.

nodes.label: Stakeholders
nodes.description: The human actors who benefit from or bear the costs of urban change: residents, workers, business owners, and caregivers. Stakeholder mapping makes equity impacts explicit and traceable.

nodes.label: Social Friction Index
nodes.description: A composite measure of community resistance to change, derived from historical trauma, displacement patterns, and trust deficits. High friction signals that density acceptance will be low regardless of technical feasibility.

nodes.label: Historical Shocks
nodes.description: Past traumatic events that shape present perception: redlining, urban renewal, foreclosure crises, and industrial plant closures. These memories persist in community consciousness long after the events themselves.

nodes.label: Demography
nodes.description: Population structure by age, household composition, and lifecycle stage. Demographic trends determine housing demand, service needs, and political constituency formation.

nodes.label: Market Potential
nodes.description: Effective demand for space: absorption rates, rent tolerance, and buyer depth. Market potential translates demographic and economic conditions into development feasibility signals.

nodes.label: Income Distribution
nodes.description: The spread of household incomes across a geography. Income distribution determines affordability thresholds and reveals who can access housing produced by the market.

nodes.label: Economic Memory
nodes.description: Institutional knowledge of past market cycles: boom-bust patterns, rent curves, and investment returns. Economic memory shapes lender behavior, investor appetite, and risk perception.

nodes.label: Fear/Preparation Index
nodes.description: A psychographic measure of collective anxiety derived from historical trauma. High fear dampens risk-taking and density acceptance; high preparation indicates adaptive capacity.

nodes.label: Displacement Risk
nodes.description: The probability that existing residents or businesses will be involuntarily displaced by rising costs or changing land use. Displacement risk is the social cost most frequently externalized by development.

nodes.label: Regime: Contested
nodes.description: A governance model prioritizing pluralist friction: litigation, public hearings, and stakeholder negotiation. Contested regimes produce slower, more legitimate decisions but struggle to achieve metabolic efficiency.

nodes.label: Regime: Directed
nodes.description: A governance model prioritizing state-led scaling and rapid deployment. Directed regimes achieve metabolic efficiency but risk legitimacy deficits and concentrated costs.

nodes.label: Jurisdictions
nodes.description: The territorial boundaries within which specific authorities exercise power: municipalities, counties, special districts, and federal enclaves. Jurisdictional fragmentation creates coordination failures.

nodes.label: Policy-as-Code
nodes.description: The translation of legislative intent into executable algorithms. Policy-as-Code enables automated compliance checking but raises questions about discretion, interpretation, and democratic accountability.

nodes.label: International Organizations
nodes.description: Supranational bodies that set standards, allocate capital, and coordinate across jurisdictions: UN-Habitat, World Bank, and regional development banks. These actors shape urban development through conditional lending.

nodes.label: Tort Law
nodes.description: The legal framework governing liability for harm. Tort law determines who bears costs when autonomous systems cause damage, shaping deployment incentives for synthetic actors.

nodes.label: Legacy Governance
nodes.description: Historical governance patterns that persist through institutional inertia: colonial administrative boundaries, mid-century zoning paradigms, and path-dependent regulatory cultures.

nodes.label: Neo-Governance
nodes.description: Emerging governance forms that operate outside traditional state structures: platform governance, algorithmic regulation, and private urban management. Neo-governance raises accountability questions.
